title: 108_s2195
content:
There is no text provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk as follows:

"SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE." The "Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2004" amends the Controlled Substances Act to define anabolic steroids as drugs related to testosterone, excluding certain substances like estrogens and corticosteroids. The "Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2004" defines various anabolic steroids related to testosterone, including compounds like 1-androstenediol, 4-androstenedione, bolasterone, boldenone, calusterone, clostebol, and dehydrochloromethyltestosterone. The "Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2004" lists various anabolic steroids related to testosterone, including compounds like 1-androstenediol, 4-androstenedione, drostanolone, fluoxymesterone, and mestanolone. The "Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2004" includes a list of anabolic steroids related to testosterone, such as mestanolone, mesterolone, methandienone, methenolone, and methyltestosterone. The "Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2004" lists various anabolic steroids including methyltestosterone, mibolerone, 17a-methyl-1-dihydrotestosterone, nandrolone, norandrostenediol, and norandrostenedione. The "Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2004" includes various anabolic steroids such as norbolethone, oxandrolone, stanozolol, and testosterone. The Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2004 lists specific anabolic steroids like dien-17-oic acid lactone, testosterone, tetrahydrogestrinone, trenbolone, and their derivatives. The Attorney General has the authority to schedule these substances. Additionally, the Act amends the Controlled Substances Act to include "anabolic steroids" after "marihuana." The criteria for classification of drugs containing anabolic steroids are also revised. The Anabolic Steroids Control Act of 1990 is amended to exempt certain drugs containing anabolic steroids from control under the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act. The Act also reorganizes and amends certain sections for clarity and consistency. The Anabolic Steroids Control Act of 1990 is amended to exempt certain drugs containing anabolic steroids from control under the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act. The amendments made by this section will take effect 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act. The United States Sentencing Commission is tasked with reviewing and potentially amending sentencing guidelines for offenses involving anabolic steroids to increase penalties and deter trafficking and use. Additionally, they are required to implement prevention and education programs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to public and nonprofit entities for science-based education programs in schools to highlight the harmful effects of anabolic steroids. Eligibility requires submitting an application, with preference given to programs like Athletes Training and Learning to Avoid Steroids and Athletes Targeting Healthy Exercise and Nutrition Alternatives. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants for education programs on anabolic steroids' harmful effects. The programs will target teachers, principals, coaches, and students. $15,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2005-2010. The National Survey on Drug Use and Health will include questions on anabolic steroids, with $1,000,000 authorized for the same fiscal years. The curr_chunk can be summarized as: 

"Speaker of the House of Representatives and Vice President of the United States."
